awd_titl_txt: GOALI: High Magnetic Anisotropy Materials for Ultrahigh Density Heat-assisted Magnetic Recording Media.
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the last six decades, the areal density of magnetic recording has increased by eight orders of magnitude. These rapid advancements have fundamentally changed information technology and the way of life. The information is stored in tiny magnets, like compasses with nanometer sizes. As each bit of information is stored over an ever-smaller volume, it is essential to use materials that are still stable at extremely small dimensions against thermal effects. This material property is known as the magnetic anisotropy, which anchors magnetic moments in place, enabling their practical use. This project aims at realizing materials with high magnetic anisotropy using convenient and benign synthesis conditions, combined with control over the material properties, towards applications in next generation ultrahigh density magnetic recording media and rare-earth-free and precious-metal-free permanent magnets. This GOALI partnership between U.C. Davis and Seagate offers an exciting opportunity to rapidly transfer research results into technology. This would potentially speed up the adaptation of the emerging heat-assisted magnetic recording technology. Advances in more powerful permanent magnets would impact numerous industry sectors, including hybrid and electric vehicles, magnetically levitated trains, wind turbines, power storage, magnetic refrigeration, etc. The partnership also provides opportunities to train junior researchers in industry research and development laboratories, in addition to excellent exposure to research experience in university and national laboratory and user facilities. The team plans to initiate and actively participate in a variety of efforts to broaden participation from underrepresented groups through internships, graduate course offering, exchange visits with Seagate, and other specific programs at the Magnetism Conference.

High magnetic anisotropy materials have critical applications in next generation ultrahigh density heat-assisted magnetic recording media as well as high energy density permanent magnets. Alloys of ordered FePt in the L10 phase is an ideal candidate for recording media applications. However, a critical challenge has been the high annealing temperature necessary to transform the as-deposited low anisotropy phase into the desirable high anisotropy one. This project will achieve high magnetic anisotropy L10 FePt-based thin films using atomic-scale multilayer sputtering and rapid thermal annealing. Magnetic properties of these materials will be tailored to achieve the desirable high anisotropy, large saturation magnetization, and low Curie temperature using ternary FePt-based alloys through proper tuning of the effective valence electron number. These approaches will be extended to realize L10 FeNi films that are alternative type of permanent magnets using earth abundant elements. A true understanding of the disorder-order phase transformation in these thin films will be gained, and quantitative evaluation of the phase fractions will be obtained. The partnership between U.C. Davis and Seagate will help to achieve L10 FePt and FeNi based alloys that can be readily synthesized, with controlled anisotropy at the atomic scale and minimized switching field distribution. Such materials have potentially transformative technological impacts, in speeding up the adaption for the emerging ultrahigh density heat-assisted magnetic recording technology and in the realization of high energy density permanent magnets that are rare-earth-free and precious-metal-free.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
High magnetic anisotropy materials have critical applications in next generation ultrahigh density heat-assisted magnetic recording (HAMR) media as well as high energy density permanent magnets. For HAMR media applications, the key bottleneck has been the availability of materials that have high magnetic anisotropy, large saturation magnetization, moderate Curie temperature, and are compatible with industrial-level processing. Alloys of ordered FePt in the tetragonal L10 phase is an ideal candidate. However, a critical challenge has been the high annealing temperature necessary to transform the as-deposited low anisotropy cubic phase into the desirable high anisotropy one.

 

Intellectual Merit

We have investigated high magnetic anisotropy materials suitable for the emerging HAMR technology using convenient and benign synthesis conditions, combined with control over magnetic anisotropy and switching characteristics. We have developed a quantitative magnetic "fingerprinting" tool to characterize the high anisotropy phases using the first-order reversal curve (FORC) method, demonstrated that the combination of ion irradiation and annealing leads to much improved L10 ordering in FePt-C/BN thin films, which are highly desirable for HAMR media applications, and distinguished the effects of different segregants on the high temperature magnetic properties of L10 FePt as HAMR media.

We have also succeeded in synthesizing high-anisotropy tetrataenite alloys via sputtering of alternating atomic layers of Fe and Ni, followed by rapid thermal annealing, which offers an important alternative to high anisotropy materials using earth-abundant elements. We have also found encouraging results in stabilizing novel types of high anisotropy phases using earth-abundant elements via the configurational entropy route.

Furthermore, we have shown that ionic transport across getter-metal /oxide interfaces is an effective means to tailor magnetic anisotropy, ferromagnetism, exchange bias, and superconductivity in a number of oxide systems. For example, electric field gating has been demonstrated to drastically enhance the exchange bias effect, which can be further modified by ion irradiation and implantation.

Finally, we have demonstrated a novel type of interconnected nanowire networks for 3-dimensional (3D) information storage, where the magnetization reversal mechanism evolves from strong demagnetizing dipolar interactions to intersections-mediated domain wall pinning and propagation, and eventually to shape-anisotropy dominated magnetization reversal. Such networks offer interesting potentials for 3D magnetic memory and logic applications. They also may be used to implement repeatable multi-state memristors in neuromorphic circuits.

Broader Impacts

This GOALI project is done with Seagate as an industry partner. It has potentially transformative technological impacts, as L10 FePt is being intensely pursued for the emerging ultrahigh density HAMR media. The convenient and benign synthesis conditions demonstrated in our studies, along with tunable magnetic properties, could substantially speed up the adaption of the HAMR technology.  Realization of tetrataenite using earth abundant elements, which led to an issued patent, may also have far-reaching impacts as an alternative rare-earth-free and precious-metal-free permanent magnet. The results on magneto-ionics have shown promise in controlling a wide variety of magnetic functionalities, using ionic migration, which can be further modulated by an electric field. They open up new opportunities for solid state magneto-ionic devices with excellent energy efficiency. New magnetic characterization capabilities developed using the FORC method are highly beneficial for the magnetism community, including reconstruction of phase-resolved hysteresis loops for multi-phase systems. Additionally, a separate study on magnetic nanoprobes for two-way magnetic resonance tuning has helped to understand the mechanisms responsible for the contrast enhancement. This method was used to detect early-stage brain tumors in a mouse model with greatly increased sensitivity.

This project has provided partial support for 6 graduate students as well as valuable research experience for a number of undergraduate students. Two students graduated with Ph.D., including one of Hispanic descent. The results have been disseminated in 20 or so refereed publications and presented in numerous invited talks at conferences and research institutes, including major conferences in the field. Students involved in the project received excellent exposure to research experience in universities, national labs and user facilities, industry R&D laboratories, and international research institutes.  Key topics of this project on magnetic recording and high magnetic anisotropy materials have been incorporated into PI's hybrid graduate/undergraduate course at Georgetown University. The PI has actively engaged in outreach activities, including presenting demonstrations and lectures to K-12 students and the general public.


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Kai Liu

    Reconstruction of phase-separated hysteresis loops of high anisotropy materials
  • An effective approach to electrically tune exchange bias is demonstrated in Gd/NiCoO thin films (top). Ionic motion across the interface induces an exchange bias effect, which can be further enhanced in an electric field (bottom) [ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces, 13, 38916 (2021)].
    Peyton Murray, Christopher Jensen, and Kai Liu
    Copyrighted
    Kai Liu
    Electrically Enhanced Exchange Bias via Solid State Magneto-Ionics
  • (a) Scanning electron microscopy images of interconnected metallic nanowire networks, where the inset shows one intersection. (b) First-order reversal curve distribution of Co networks in different geometries relative to the applied field [Nano Lett. 21, 716 (2021)].
    Edward Burks, Dustin Gilbert and Kai Liu
    Copyrighted
    Kai Liu
    3-dimensional interconnected nanowire networks
  • The PI has given many public demonstrations and talks about magnetism to K-12 students and the general public, including at the 2018 USA Science & Engineering Festival in Washington, DC.
    Kai Liu
